title: Wednesday, 20th March 2019
bodyHTML:
11:07 am
BE11:07am

Okay, good luck everyone.

SupposeToBeWorking... Morning
VV75 morning
Soundbuy Hello all
BE11:08am

Yesterday's session was terminated at the midpoint due to a four-minute wobble in a third-party bit of software we rely upon.

Flaneur Wha's poppin' fam'?
cheeckychappy Time for some dinner party live?
DogDay Morning all

Apologies to you, the valued reader. And thank you to our tech team for spending much of yesterday staring under the bonnet and hitting things with spanners.

Alice Yes, we switched it off and on again
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Morning all.

Shinshin "which bandit fitted this GPU in the first place ?"

But I'm not that, so let's give Ben full credit.

https://www.betavi...-inmarsat-said-to/

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 516.60, up 78.8 (+18.00%), High: 516.80, Low: 500.76, Volume: 11.77m
Excel Developer #FTTech: I switched browsers from Chrome to Edge and the FT home page is different. For years I've been shown a mobile/tablet FT home page.
Tom Dalgleish Good evening. Evening is drinking time. Sake
Excel Developer which means either nobody tests or nobody cares.
BE11:13am

Seems this was the UK takeover that's been muttered about for a while now, so everyone can stand down. Course, if Inmarsat had told us about it six weeks ago when the approach arrived, there wouldn't have been quite so much gossip around ......

PBateman Good morning
BE11:13am

And there was speculation around in the press -- https://www.ft.com...-bb0c-42459962a812 -- just that it was pointed towards trade rather than PE.

red @Tom Dalgleishyou clearly dont have kids. here its homework and boardgames
11:13 am
BE11:14am

Anyway. Let's recap where we are.

DJ Morning
BE11:14am

I'll let Goldman do it .....

BE11:14am

Following press reports (FT) about a potential PE offer, Inmarsat has confirmed it received a non-binding proposal from a PE consortium on 31 January regarding a possible cash offer at $7.21 (equates to 542p at 1.33 FX), a c24% premium to March 19 closing share price (438p). We note the PE consortium now has until 16 April to make a firm offer. ISAT notes the proposal remains under discussion between ISAT and the PE consortium.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

No! Not "following press reports (FT)" ... wasn't us.

Pete Morning
BE11:15am

Among the bid consortium, Apax is the most interesting name.

BE11:15am

Firstly because Apax used to own Inmarsat.

Tom Dalgleish @Red, it was working time for me
11:16 am
BE11:16am

Secondly, because its owns Marlink, which sells Inmarsat satphones for boats.

BE11:16am

It's one of the key distributors. Which makes this look relatively friendly, potentially. Which is a point Exane makes.

BE11:17am

We think Inmarsat's management is likely to favour a takeprivate
bid (vs. a take-over scenario) especially if it comes with the strategic benefit of closer integration with Marlink.

Tom Dalgleish Kids made for 60 hour weeks
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Course, against that we have to spin back to the robust rejection Echostar was given just eight months ago.

BE11:18am

Its bid being 532p, of which 265p was cash, so basically no different in terms of headline valuation to the PE one.

Roidster One just raised 1.5bln.....softbank may come in ...thoughts?
BE11:18am

"If you engage at a level that's way below what you think is the right level, all you're doing is signaling weakness and a willingness to trade value below fair value"; "And after all, we're not for sale. We don't feel weak about our future and we don't feel the need to engage in a merger even with somebody in our industry at this point in time. We don't think that will drive exceptional value for shareholders beyond the value they've paid on the way into that kind of environment. So, that's why we did not engage".

Roidster Oneweb
11:18 am

That was Inmarsat's CEO in August.

Roidster Dam autospell
Tom Dalgleish Seikyo gunmai ginjo omachi. Midway between wine and spirits.

Next, we have to examine the conspiracy theory angle.

BE11:19am

Here's Jefferies:

11:19 am
BE11:19am

The decision to unilaterally disclose the Consortium's six-week-old non-binding cash bid, almost identical in value to the rejected 3-Jul-18 EchoStar bid, feels like a well-advised "stalking horse" that could well now result in a revised bid (from either suitor).

BE11:20am

Except it wasn't unilaterally disclosed. It was in response to a specific report, so that doesn't quite work.

Viking1 I see Google fined another 1.7 bill by the feisty Dane
PBateman any brexit grey? I am despairing now

And to follow that, we need to get knee deep in the binary value around Ligado (the former Lightsquared, messes with GPS, you remember) and strategic value to Charlie Ergen .....

Manxish Hello everyone
11:24 am
BE11:24am

... unfortunately, Barclays has gone restricted and Wilton Fry at RBC doesn't seem to be around this morning, so we'll go for Numis.

Punter Any grey on Kier's H1 results please as foretold it looks to me but shares down 8% on them
BE11:25am

● In FY18, L-band services earned 81% of ISAT's total business unit sales and were -4% YoY. Ka-band (fast broadband) services earned the balance and were +85% YoY. Total business unit revenue was +6% YoY. In L-band, ISAT faced much more competition in FY18 and will likely face even more competition now Iridium (IRDM) is commercialising its new and superior L-band network (at its CMD this month, IRDM detailed why it will hurt ISAT). IRDM is a much stronger rival in Maritime now, but soon also in Government, Aviation and Enterprise. In Ka-band, we think ISAT lacks network capacity so more In-Flight Connectivity (IFC) contracts will require more significant capex. As a result, we are concerned that IFC revenue growth will not result in commensurate FCF growth.

A. M. @Viking1: well done her, indeed.
BE11:25am

● We doubt Echostar will bid again as some of its likely hoped for benefits were long shots: (i) ISAT can leverage Echostar's Ka-band network if it decides to enter the ultracompetitive IFC market in the US; (ii) one day, authorities will let Echostar combine the only two pan-European S-band licenses and, also, repurpose them for terrestrial use.

Tom Dalgleish Purely on the chart, Inmarsat looks good buying
jaws BE anything in Learning technology from B berg today note or peel yesterday note please
11:25 am
BE11:25am

And Goldman.

BE11:26am

Our 12-month price target for ISAT is 480p (which is split 400p core value and 80p value for Ligado). The disclosed possible offer price is 13% above our price target. From a leverage perspective, we note ISAT (excluding Ligado lease payments in 2019) will on our estimates see net debt/EBITDA rising to 3.6x, although the peer group leverage (SES, ETL and Intelsat) varies significantly (3-9x). For ISAT we do not forecast positive FCF until 2021 given high levels of capex in the medium term as it refreshes it L-Band fleet (two new satellites) and launches incremental GX satellites.

red @PBatemanon a scale, where last week no deal was being scaled down to less than 10%, its now being scaled back up slightly. problem is mkt cannot really price it properly given any outcome is still a binary event.
BE11:26am

Implied deal valuation c8x EV/EBITDA. While we do not take a view on the likelihood of a firm offer materialising, we note that at the possible offer price, this would imply a take-out multiple of 7.9x 2019E EV/EBITDA (vs 6.9x at the current share price) and 4.2% normalised 2019E FCF yield (smoothed for LT capex) vs 5.2% at the current share price. We note FY19 earnings are depressed by high Aero investments in inflight Wifi. This compares to peers SES/ETL trading on 9.7x/6.4x 2019E EV/EBITDA.

11:26 am
undefined

What do we have in requests? Genel, Kier, Learning Technology ....

We can come to all of those in time.

wayneJ @red - in that context the following is worth reading - https://ukhumanrightsblog.com/2019/03/19/no-deal-brexit-may-be-unlawful-a-view-from-rose-slowe/

Over in Germany we have Bayer.

Or rather, it was a "substantial factor" in one poor chap's Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma.

Viking1 Will Monsanto be liable as well?
VV75 It's not like Bayer was not warned to take over Monsanto..Immense value destruction since, jeez
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian I've got some Roundup in the greenhouse. :(
red @1st Lt. Fletcher Christianhes no better or worse than other city type who would all sell their grandmothers for a tenner
Pharma #Brexit something non-partisan and quite interesting:https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2019/03/the-brexit-paradox-that-spells-doom-for-the-independent-group/
Dec69 - Skeptic Good Morning
BE11:31am

This was the worst of the range of expected outcomes. Here's Caz:

Markkus Do you have to fall into a vat of the stuff, or merely spray some in your garden?
BE11:31am

This decision means that the trial now moves to Phase 2 in which jurors will decide whether Bayer/Monsanto is legally liable for the harm caused to Mr. Hardeman and, if so, what the damages should be. As the case had been bifurcated in Phase 2 of the trial the plaintiff’s lawyers are allowed to present evidence about Monsanto’s alleged actions to control or manipulate the scientific record and claims that Monsanto has worked to suppress evidence of harm with its herbicides, evidence that was excluded from Phase 1 of the trial. After the verdict from Phase 1 we would expect the jury to find Bayer liable for Mr. Hardeman’s cancer but assessing the size of potential damages remains challenging. Although all the cases are different we believe that the verdict in this case increases the likelihood that the 3rd jury trial starting in California on March 28th will also be lost, especially given that this case is of a husband and wife who both have been diagnosed with NHL. Overall given expectations in the market that the bifurcation of the Hardeman case would increase the chances of success for Bayer/Monsanto we would expect the market to be disappointed today. Therefore we see the stock reversing some of the gains made this year and expect the shares to be down over 5% today.

wayneJ @red - may be; but for a dramatic measure like brexit one would think that (i) you want to build consenus (ii) you want everything to be legally watertight
11:32 am
BE11:32am

(@Markkus: most of the evidence seems unconvincing that either would do you too much harm, though I guess falling into a vat of it has a drowning risk.)

Dec69 - Skeptic I'm surprised by the verdict on Bayer, I expect too much is being placed on the $ damages.
Pharma Only problem with that judgement is that glyphosate does not cause cancer.The courts and jury trials should not be used to make policy or scientific judgements.
VV75 @Markkus, the patient in this particular lawsuit used 6000 gallons of the stuff on his land
BE11:33am

So, we're back to making wild guesses on liability. Phase 2 on that starts today.

Tom Dalgleish @Dec69 there are many headlines about US damage awards but aren't they scaled back somehow?
BE11:34am

Kepler incoming:

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Our equity analyst has modelled three scenarios of potential damages to
settle the 11,000 Roundup cases pending across the US. A 10% probability
of paying limited damage (i.e. Monsanto wins all trials), 50% probability of
c. USD5bn pay out (which it seems is close to some consensus), and 40%
change of a pay out in the EUR20bn range.

Dec69 - Skeptic I had to double take for a minute, I thought we were honored by MB from Wirecard joining us. Apologies for the mistake Markkus.
BE11:34am

Beyond the financial risk, this negative news flow adds to the reputational
risk of Monsanto, which could reflect on future earnings. The performance
of Bayer’s bonds will be driven by the group’s ability to deliver on expected organic deleveraging (factored into all three agencies’ base-case scenarios). The potential pay-out (with a large tail risk in case of a worst case scenario) and potential impact on future earnings create uncertainty on the evolution of the group’s credit profile, and will weigh on the bonds. The spread offered does not compensate for this, and we downgrade our
recommendation to Sell. We add that the shorter hybrid specifically (call
2020) has a reset spread of 217bps versus a 5Y refinancing, at least in the
350-400bp area, which creates an extension risk (still capped by the
sizable hybrid curve of the group though).

Pharma @Markus, for some context, there is an LD50 value (dose at which 50% of test subjects die) for water.
PBateman @red what's the no deal trade then, (not that i see it happening)
Dec69 - Skeptic TOM D, I think the fear is its a class settlement so may be high. I don't invest in Bayer, never will, if I can't describe the company in two minutes its too complex for my tiny brain.
Viking1 Monsanto last year was fine 289, post appeal it was cut to 78.5 mill?
PBateman short cable / long ftse100 but after the initial panic selling?
BE11:35am

And Barclays ......

red @wayneJit is watertight, the eu have said so. and they are keen for us to stay. there is WA, if its not taken up, its not the EU's fault.
11:35 am
BE11:36am

At a minimum we expect the result to extend the overhang and uncertainty associated with the litigation and continue to detract from investors focusing on business fundamentals/underlying value and being deterred by a volatility and liability they feel is impossible to predict. Nonetheless, we note the stock reaction this morning (c-10%) has put Bayer back toward recent lows and continues to imply a €15-20bn liability impact in our view (i.e. all else equal we believe Bayer would be trading closer to €90/sh i.e. a low-teens forward P/E multiple of 13x, which our €85 PT reflects with a €5bn liability adjustment). Whilst yesterday’s result likely pushes the ultimate settlement cost closer to the upper bound of our prior estimate range of €1-5bn, until we have reason to believe that figure will be significantly different (at present we don’t), we continue to think the present special situation continues to offer an opportunity for those able to weather the short-term turbulence (and pain).

Skatersav IQE numbers look great...
Dec69 - Skeptic @Skatesav, being short there, I had to double check I'd read the correct results. I like your sarcasm.
BE11:37am

So, probably fine on liability numbers so long as you don't pay much attention to the deleveraging timeline, in which case you're in trouble.

red @PBatemanbuy sterling and uk assets after the initial mark down on no deal. cable will be circa 1.20 maybe less. but they will be the low points. no deal is not a final destination. the final destination is always a trade agreement, the only question is how we get there. anything else is temporary and should be taken advantage of

Ccmpany warns about an unwind of inflated VCSEL inventory levels, which I guess echoes the stuff coming out of regular handset parts suppliers.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Management, never likely to under-promise, suggests the inventory effect will be “temporary" with “significant growth” coming thereafter.

BE11:41am

Dec69 - Skeptic My summary of IQE, a fish requiring a clubbing on the bank. Its just time till they a) need more cash or b) sell off / BO, for very little premium. Obviously my own opinion. Being an unsophisticated person.
BE11:41am

Management has provided a specific 2019 outlook as well as tweaks to the long-term framework. Guidance for greater than 50% Photonics growth is highly encouraging, supporting our view of a strong Android 3DS/VCSEL ramp. However, the ~15% decline in wireless $ revenues this year surprised and seems driven by elevated inventories as well as the structural trend of lower power amplifier content in smartphones. On the bright side, demand for GaN-related products is strong, though not large enough yet to compensate.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Assuming $/£ of ~1.3, we estimate guidance implies 2019 revenues of ~£173m (vs CGe £181m) and adj. operating profit of greater than £17.3m (vs CGe £23m). As anticipated, revenues will be backend-loaded with an expected 40:60 H1/H2 split. For 2020 we believe guidance implies growth of around 20% yoy. Management fine-tuned the 3-5 yr framework with wireless growth raised (0-20% vs 0-10%) to reflect the 5G filter opportunity, and Photonics growth steered towards the lower end of the 40%-60% range.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian "why do i get put on pending when replying to 1st Lt. Fletcher Christian?" Probably, I do tend to ruffle feathers.
BE11:42am

We had expected a pullback in investments this year, but management continues to step on the gas and ramp new Photonics capacity, likely reflecting confidence in the demand trajectory. 2019 Capex guidance of £50-55m (incl. development) coupled with lower PTP will probably lead to higher FCF burn this year compared to our current -£10m estimate. However, 2020 Capex is guided to drop to ~£25-30m, lower than our currently modeled £30m and likely implying positive FCF next year.

BE11:43am

There's a(nother) new CFO in here, to remind. And until he gets fully up to speed, the idea that H1 is a trough for earnings would appear to be theoretical.

11:43 am
undefined
red lol
BE11:45am

@Dec69: I offer no editorialising about the stock you mention.

The obvious thing to say relates to rats and sinking ships, but the average B&Q has enough MDF in stock to float for a wee while. Spinning back to figures, they're okay versus lowered expectations rather than good.

Bluesky21 Are we being a bit too harsh on Kingfisher? It's not as if Homebase has done any better ... it seems more a sector-wide problem
BE11:52am

Here comes Socgen:

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Home improvement can be a messy business and that is the impression we have of Kingfisher’s full-year results today. For the year to January 2019, Kingfisher has reported PBT before exceptionals and transformation costs of £693m, compared with our figure of £696m and consensus (provided by the company) of £685m. However, until recently, consensus was closer to £705m. Looking at the guidance elements for the year to January 2020e supplied by the company today, consensus EPS could fall by around 5%.

BE11:53am

The original target of a £500m addition to PBT from the transformation plan by FY21e has effectively been abandoned. In reality, while some benefits are likely to come through, it is not easy to separate these out from the business as a whole. The year to January 20e would have been year four of the plan, when significant gross margin benefits from unified sourcing were supposed to start coming through, but the gross margin guidance for next year is "flat", which includes around -20bp in the UK and slightly up in France.

red @Bluesky21internet is the prob. when stuff is generic, you buy where cheapest
BE11:53am

In terms of @Bluesky21's question, "is it the company or the market?"

Bluesky21 @red - true. But Home Depot and Lowes in the US have been fine
11:53 am
BE11:53am

I'd suggest it's a bit of both .....

BE11:54am

Note, for example, Kingfisher's closing 19 Screwfix Germany shops.

BornCynic How is Paul's house in Moz holding up BE?

We also have the epic task of simplifying rawlplug suppliers. Now on for 60-65% unified stock by January 2020.

Why on earth has this taken so long?

Bluesky21 Also, about 10-15% of Home Depot and Lowes sales are appliances - washing machines and the like ... market share taken from the likes of Sears in recent years

And why hasn't, for example, Dixons had the same issues with online etc? It's managed to use its last-man-standing position on the high street to price gouge. Why does it work for hi-fi and not chainsaws?

Bluesky21 @BE Thanks for the Screwfix in Germany point
Tom Dalgleish @Bonnemort, I have a workshop full
11:57 am
BE11:57am

SocGen again.

SoS @Pharma I bet Jeremy Corbyn would try

BE11:57am

The shares look likely to fall by at least 5% today if they are to track the possible downgrade to consensus EPS. The current year (Jan. 20e) P/E valuation of between 10x and 11x (following the likely move in consensus EPS) is not cheap in our view given the negative earnings momentum and ongoing risks. We maintain our Sell rating on Kingfisher.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @Pharma Yes, but you can kill HTB and let the market find true value and put that £10Bn plus into better things. That £10bn is pretty much turned out to be all builder margin.
Bonnemort Screwfix was great when it first started. Not anywhere near as cheap now. Toolstation better for most things.
Bluesky21 @BE Personally I think the UK is too crowded
BE11:58am

And Davy.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Kingfisher has been running hard but its profits have stood still.
Despite all the efforts of the ‘ONE Kingfisher’ project, the group’s
retail profits in the year to end-January 2019 were little changed
from where they were at the outset of the programme. France in
particular remains a persistent headache and continues to place
downward pressure on forecasts. We believe the latter limits the
stock’s potential to re-rate despite screening attractively from a
value perspective. The disruption at senior management level –
with a CEO succession process now underway – adds a further
layer of uncertainty.

undefined
Bluesky21 Being a "big shed" retailer is much better if your sheds are mostly surrounded by empty space and it takes forever to deliver
Bonnemort @Bluesky - agreed. Way too crowded. And round my way more and more housing going up.
Dec69 - Skeptic 1st Fletcher, the Help to Buy (HTB) you refer to has distorted prices in poorer areas since inception. So much so, they aren't meant to offer discounts for Non-Htb, amazingly we evidence this at two listed companies in 2017/18. Obviously those administering the scheme don't care, it's only UK Gov's cash after all.
Bluesky21 The same is probably true of Walmart vs. Tesco
red hifi is to a degree discretionary. as for tools, folks tend to buy the cheapest they can. while tradesmen dont use places such stores for purchases.

Again, landlords benefit from the tax payer on council tax relief for multi-occupancy accomodation. My advice to our youth would be, leave the country. Better value elsewhere.

Learning Technologies Group PLC (LTG:LSE): Last: 76.20, down 2.8 (-3.54%), High: 80.00, Low: 75.60, Volume: 2.11m

12:03 pm

BE12:04pm

We are Sellers of Learning Tech because:

The track record of strong organic growth, often referenced by management, is misleading. We calculate an average of just 4% since 2008 and 2018 at 0% (ex-CSL).
A build up of deferred income in acquired companies could be used to flatter future growth.
Competition in the LMS (Learning Management System) space is intensifying as startups enter and large technology players invest.
We think 25% margin targets are leading to structural under-investment and endangering the core business' competitive strength.
Pressure to invest in headcount is likely to lead to margin compression from 27% in 2022 to 16% in 2027.
Our forecasts produce an intrinsic value of 40p, c50% downside, which could still look generous given organic revenue cagr of greater than 5% over 10 years and terminal EBIT margins of 16%.

BE12:10pm

Interim results look lower than expected at the underlying operating profit level (c.-4%). As expected, there are more exceptional cost items (including Broadmoor Hospital at c.£25m and curtailment of loss-making Waste contract at c.£26m). Net debt is in line with the revised guidance issued recently. FPK looks to be progressing as expected with c.£20m of benefit expected to be seen in FY2020, after having a neutral effect this year. It is reassuring that the group continues to make good contract wins with a mixed trading backdrop currently, as expected. Clearly, post the rights issue the balance sheet is stronger, which should result in better working capital movements going forward and average net debt reducing to c.£200m for FY2020. The new CEO starts soon and we would expect him to continue delivering the FPK programme and focus more on the balance sheet, making a strategic decision around what the capitalization and balance sheet of the group should look like over the medium term. Guidance is unchanged but we would not be surprised to see the top end edge lower and confidence around the numbers is likely to remain questionable given recent developments and first half underlying profits have missed. The shares look lowly rated on current consensus forecasts but we would not expect a near-term re-rating until evidence of reliable delivery is seen.
